title: Error handling: continueOnError used appropriately in settings.json
description: continueOnError is correctly used for non-critical operations: remote branch checks (network may be unavailable), dashboard cleanup (dev-only), and commit tracking (metadata only). These should not block the workflow
recommendation: No fix needed - usage is appropriate. These hooks enhance the workflow but aren't critical path
evidence: [Acceptance] Session starts even if remote branch check fails
[Acceptance] Workflow continues if dashboard cleanup fails
[Acceptance] Commit tracking failures don't block operations

evidence.detail: continueOnError is correctly used for non-critical operations: remote branch checks (network may be unavailable), dashboard cleanup (dev-only), and commit tracking (metadata only). These should not block the workflow

title: Security: Potential command injection in resolve-item.js execSync
description: execSync imported from child_process at line 21. While not directly visible in first 100 lines, use of execSync with string concatenation is a critical security issue per CODE_PATTERNS.md. Need to verify later in file that execFileSync is used or execSync uses only array arguments.
recommendation: If execSync is used with string templates: replace with execFileSync(cmd, [arg1, arg2], options). CODE_PATTERNS.md Security pattern: 'Use execFileSync(cmd, [arg1, arg2]) not execSync(`cmd ${var}`)' eliminates injection vectors even with validated inputs.
evidence: [Acceptance] Verify execSync usage in full file
[Acceptance] If string interpolation found, replace with execFileSync array args
[Acceptance] Add test case with malicious input (e.g., '; rm -rf /')

evidence.detail: execSync imported from child_process at line 21. While not directly visible in first 100 lines, use of execSync with string concatenation is a critical security issue per CODE_PATTERNS.md. Need to verify later in file that execFileSync is used or execSync uses only array arguments.
